Touchdown: ^s: Your ship touches down. This is it - the

^.
A lithe, anxious seeming middle aged man rushes to your door once you land, followed by a small flock of people. They turn gawk at the side of the ship, where "Trailway Railways & Trade" is painted boldly.
^n: Hello! Hello, how are you, how was the airspace, how are you doing - it is absolutely WONDEROUS to see you.

c-0: ^. I see you are energetic as always!
g-0: ^n: Well then. I hope you have worked up an appetite, because we have quite the dinner prepared!

^s: He starts walking towards the settlement and beckons you to follow. He passes several buildings, pointing out their usefulness until you arrive at a small, cozy banquet hall. He leads you to sit at a long table in the corner.
^n: Ah, how we’ll be in the history books. Imagine, second Earth’s largest metropolis, started right here in this very town.
^s: He gazes off in the distance as plates of steaming food are placed in front of you.

s: ^p: I'm glad to see you are as excited as I am!

g-1: ^s: You plow into the food. While the taste is good, the meat is oddly... crunchy? Like there's... sand? Is that... bone?

c-4: ^p: This texture is... leaving something to be desired. Could you not come up with something better?
c-5: ^ p: The flavor of this meal is divine.

g-2: ^n: That is our region's delicacy... fresh Moostac, caught just yesterday and brought in with a day's travel.

FoodComplaint: ^n: I fear we are limited in our options before trade with Earth is better established. We just don't have the same kind of infrastructure established here just yet.
^n: It won't be long though! Perhaps next time we can try something else.

s0: ^QuestionsAndAnswers == 0: n: Well, speaking of next time, I know our time is short before you have to move on to work with the other settlements. Do you have any questions for me?

b: ^ n: Do you have any more questions?

s: ^p: What's the best way to convince the settlements to join us?
^p: Where did you get such a fine suit?

c-0: ^n: Why, I'm sure everyone will be estatic to join your railway network. Why wouldn't they be?

s: ^p: I think if that were the case, we would have received more responses in our outreach...

c-0: ^n: Well, I'm sure they just need a little more convincing. I'm sure after a little conversation it will become clear what will make them say yes.

c-1: ^n: Oh my. Why thank you. I have a wonderful tailor here, his name is Sherry, let me give you his card...

EarthSnacks: ^n: Just so you know, I heard Gula is itching to increase shipments of Earth Snacks. If you hook her up, I'm sure she'll be jumping to join in no time.
CompleteCity: ^s: After your meal, you have a quiet evening in one of
^'s Apartment Pods to prepare for your next day of travels.

City2: ^s: You travel to the second settlement.

Entrance: ^n: Greetings, crusty traveler. You must be from

s: ^p: Greetings, that's right madam. I just finished a fine stay with
^ and made quick work of the trip here.

g-0: ^n: Well, I'm sure you got our searing response that said we have no interest in your business here.

s: ^p: Yes, we heard. I thought perhaps an in-person visit would be regarded more warmly.
^ spoke so highly of you over dinner. I couldn't leave this planet without at least stopping in.

c-2: ^n: Well, I fear you were about as wrong as it would be to have dinner for breakfast.
^p: No need to be salty about it.
c-3: ^s: She docks her head to the side.
^n: Well... I gander he'll say a nice thing or two about just about anyone I dare say!

s: ^p: I think he said it was Mooskrat.

g-1: ^s: She closes her eyes and nods.

b: ^n: You just don't take no for an answer, do you. Fine, I will humor some questions. But don't get too sticky and think this means we will be joining your rail network.

s0: ^ I suppose I can answer a few questions.
s1: ^ What do you have for me?
s2: ^ What would you like to know?

s: ^p: Can you tell me a little bit about Gwuff Hills?
^p: Can you tell me more about this coal?
^p: What can I do to sweeten the pot for you?
^p: Do you happen to like... snacks?
^p: Perhaps we could throw in a steady supply of Earth Snacks to satiate your disinterest in joining.

c-0: ^n: Gwuff Hills, yes. Well. You see that we are surrounded by a delicate ring of mountains. I've have you know we are the number one server of coal in the area.
c-1: ^n: Our fine coal has a nicely done charr that embodies their smoky undertone, which is clear in their darkened appearance and crispy texture. They burn bright cherry-red to get the work done that needs doing.
c-2: ^n: S-Sweeten the...  I told you we have no interest in joining, yes? Try again.
c-3: ^n: There is no snack that deserves that title unless you are referring to... wait, what?
^p: What if we got you some... Earth snacks?

CompleteCity: ^s: Gula Gwuff's face suddenly completely changes.
^n: Ahem, I mean, what is this plan you say, regarding Earth Smack-Snackery?

s: ^p: If you join our network, I'll make sure you don't run a single day without a steady stock of Earth Snacks.
^p: I'll bring you so many Earth Snacks, you'll run through your coal supply throwing the overstock in the incinerator.
^p: Our company will personally make sure your supply of Earth Snacks is never again what this place lacks.

g-0: ^n: Well then, I think you have yourself a deal.

s: ^p: Can you tell me about the area?
^p: I'm here to meet you, actually.
^p: I want to make a business proposition.

c-2: ^ I'm afraid I don't know much.

Exit: ^n: No bother at all, friend! Come back through any time.
BadExit: ^n: Clearly ye've got no sense about ye, friend. Come back when ye're ready to talk like a reasonable person.
BilgeName: ^n: Oh, and I suppose you think a name like "Steven" isn't strange, aye? Names come in all sorts, friend.
^n: Bilge is a family name, going back for generations. The Bilges are always there for others, to bail them out.

c-0: ^, I'm just not used to names like that.

TornsburgInfo: ^n: Ye've come to the jewel of the mountains, friend! Tornsburg is a hard place, but the people here are harder.
^n: We come from a world much less hospitable than this one. Fully of craggy ice and beasties that kill on sight.
^n: Any challenge that may arise, I assure you that we'll be more than capable of facing it.

c-0: ^, you certainly look like people that can handle themselves.
c-1: ^, it's hard to imagine coming from such a harsh place!
c-2: ^, but I have no doubt that you are a capable people.
g-0: ^n: Indeed. What brings you around to these parts?

s: ^p: I heard the stories about you
^p: I'm learning more about settlements in the area

c-3: ^, I'm glad to see the truth of them!
c-4: ^, thought I might take a look around.

TornsburgArea: ^n: Tornsburg is in rocky lands, but ye'll be hard-pressed to find a more rich place.
^n: We've laid claim to all these mountains here, and the ores within them.

s: ^p: That's all, just a bunch of rocks?

ValuableOres: ^n: Are ye mad? Ore is the heart of any great civilization. Ye can't build a massive sprawling city on the surface without first digging deep under the ground.

s: ^p: You clearly know what you're talking about

c-0: ^, I didn't think about it that way.
c-1: ^ I don't mean to challenge you.

OresUseful: ^n: Aye, with iron ores from our mountains, this could one day be a metropolis to rival old Earth.
Ores: ^n: Iron ores, that's what kind! The biggest iron ore veins ye'll find for hundreds of miles.

s: ^p: How do you mine that ore
^p: Sounds like a lot of work.
^p: Iron ore doesn't seem that valuable.

MiningOres: ^n: We've got shafts running deep through these mountains, carving them out from the inside. It's dark and dirty work, but we'll overcome it.

s: ^p: I can't imagine being that far underground

c-1: ^ I would have nightmares from something like that.
g-0: ^n: Ha, ye're exactly right! It's an awful job, but someone needs to do it!

s: ^p: I'm setting up a rail system all throughout the region.
^p: I'm creating a trade network between all the nearby settlements.
^p: I'm improving the lives of all settlements in this area.

g-0: ^n: Hm, not every day I hear about something like that. How are you managing that?

s: ^p: I work for Trailways Railways & Tradeways.
^p: I work for that one rail company with the ridiculous name.

g-1: ^n: Ah, I've heard a little bit about ye before. Ye've been going around to settlements making offers and such.

Proposition: ^n: What are ye offering, that ye think we need?

s: ^p: Well, I'm not sure yet, actually.
^p: Can I ask you a few questions?

c-2: ^, have you thought of setting up steel production?
c-3: ^, have you thought of setting up steel production?

SteelProduction: ^n: Now that's an idea, and one we've thought of before, but we haven't the resources to do something like that.
^n: Ye need a steady supply of good coal to make steel.

s: ^p: Coal is something I can provide
^p: I think I have what you need

c-0: ^, Gwuff Hills has already agreed to join our rail network.
c-1: ^, have you heard of Gruff Hills? We've already set up rail lines there.
g-0: ^n: Gwuff Hills! They've joined you already? Now that is an interesting fact...

b: ^ Ha, this isn't yer first negotiation, is it!
^Yer lucky to have such good tactics to make up for yer lack of tact.

g-0: ^ People like ye know te come prepared already!
^n: Alright, friend. If joining your network means access to coal, we can set up a steel industry right here in Tornsburg.

FirstVisit: ^s: You make your way to the
^. A dirt path brings you through wide fields with occasional crop plots. The plants droop lazily, but are peppered with bright shades of every color on the rainbow.
^s: A women, dressed in all black, peeks at you from the bottom of her sunhat.

c-0: ^n: "Expecting you? No, I am just noting your arrival.

s: ^p: "What am I? Don't you mean WHO am I?"

c-2: ^n: "I meant exactly as I asked." She twirls her hair around her finger, absentmindedly.
c-3: ^n: "I am a plant whisperer, of course! I'm suprised you had to ask!"

Welcome: ^, where the plants whisper to us their needs."

b: ^ She curtsies, exposing the depth of blackness in the layers of her skirt.

s: ^p: "Thank you! I'm happy to be here."

c-0: ^n: "Of course. Can't you hear them?" She closes her eyes, raising her chin slightly.

s0: ^ "So, what is is that I can help you with?"

s: ^p: "I am here to share details about my company,

s1: ^"I'm good for now. I'm sure we will speak again."

AboutCity: ^n: "We are a city of simple farmers. Our plants need us, you see. We rely on each other to make this a peaceful space. While the work can be slow, we are all quite happy here."

s: ^p: "We are working to connect all settlements in
^p: "What would you say if we could help you streamline your food production?"

b: ^ s: She looks a bit shocked.
^ n: "Now what good would that do us?"

s: ^p: "Well... your plants could... have more friends?"

c-0: ^n: "While I do admit they are quite sociable, I'm not sure they would like their air space intruded with the sounds and smells of transit. We must decline."

s: ^p: "We are working together to make the world a better place."

c-0: ^s: She looks down at her fingertips, examining a nail.

s: ^p: "What would you say if we could help you streamline your food production?"

IMustGo: ^n: "Yes, I've heard this a number of times now. I'm afraid I must be off."

s0: ^ She curtsies again. "I'm glad our crops got to breathe in a new face."

CompleteCity: ^n: "That would be quite lovely, wouldn't it? Consider us a part of your group."

City5: ^n: Ah, it seems we have a visitor on our doorstep. Is there something we can do for you?

b: ^ The name's Dellorithy, sweety. Welcome to the wonderful little village of Bridginggale.
^So nice to see you again here in Bridginggale.
^How nice of you to grace us with your presence.

s0: ^We have bathhouses to wash off all that... I hope it's dirt.
s1: ^If you're looking for a dentist, there may be one a few settlements over.
s2: ^Are those what pass as shoes nowaways? One of our cobblers may have an opening.
s3: ^Those tatters are an interesting fashion choice, or is that some kind of political statement?

s: ^p: I represent Trailways Railways and Tradeways
^p: I represent Trailways Railways and Tradeways
^p: I wanted to check back in with you
^p: I wanted to check back in with you
^p: This place seems different from the other settlements nearby
^p: What are all these robots everywhere?
^p: What are all these robots everywhere?
^p: Dan in Mudwood said you have great taste
^p: I think I should be going.

c-7: ^, he thinks you are very fashionable.

BadExit: ^n: Hmph, well I never. Come back when you're ready to behave in a more civilized manner.
RepresentativeIntro: ^n: Oh, that little operation? I heard there was something like that going around. I think it's cute for people to try and band together.

s: ^p: You don't sound like you want to join.
^p: We're trying to build a trade network in the area.

g-0: ^n: New Bridginggale has no need of trade with all these other little settlements nearby. No doubt they would be jumping to trade with us, though.

s: ^p: Why would they be jumping to trade with you?

g-1: ^n: We have gold, darling. We mine it from the lands down by the river. That gold allows us to trade off-world for everything that we need.
^n: That's how we sustain ourselves here. For the five years since we arrived and started mining the gold.
^n: You're welcome to pass by, but if you're thinking we'll join your network, I'm afraid you'll be disappointed.

HostileRepresentativeIntro: ^n: Oh, that little operation? I heard there was something like that going around.
^n: I also heard that your little network is backing Mudwood's claim to the lands around the river. That land rightfully belongs to us.
^n: The gold from that river was what sustained our way of life here. You've ruined us, we'll be starving within a year.

s: ^p: I thought it was the right thing to do

c-0: ^, I didn't mean to hurt anyone.
c-1: ^, I had no idea it would hurt you so much.
g-0: ^n: Well you should have thought more about your actions. How are we going to pay for the basic necessities around here without that gold?

RepresentativeConvince: ^n: Oh yes, still out here trying to join up the settlements, are you? I'm sorry, but we're still not interested.

s: ^p: What if I could help with the river?
^p: The company will help you with the river.
^p: Are you sure you don't want to join?

c-2: ^n: I am quite sure, I assure you. We have no need for this rail network. Now if you'll excuse me, I have other matters to attend to.

HostileRepresentativeConvince: ^n: Since you've decided to help prevent us from accessing the river, I don't think there's anything else we have to talk about.

s: ^What if you had a supply of cheap food?
^I'd like to help, but I'm not sure how.

c-1: ^n: Well, when you figure out how to right your mistake, then you can come and let us know.

FoodOffer: ^n: Cheap food? How dare you even offer. Our food here is imported from old Earth. We have real meat and rare delicacies every day.

s: ^p: You can't sustain that way of life.

g-0: ^n: I can't believe I'm even entertaining this, but I suppose you have a point.
^n: You're saying that there is a supply of cheap food in your rail network?

s: ^p: You'll be able to trade with
^p: There's a lot of places to trade with nearby

g-1: ^n: I did hear that they were recently able to step up to a large-scale farming operation...
^n: Grains and vegetables they have, I'm sure, but we would be lacking in caviar and ostrich...
^n: Very well, I suppose if it's a matter of life or death we need to trade more freely with nearby cities.

s: ^p: We're happen to have you on board.

g-2: ^n: I can only hope that one day I feel the same.

RiverOffer: ^n: Oh? What do you have in mind?

c-0: ^ If you're part of the network, others would legitimize your claim.
c-1: ^ If you're part of the network, others would legitimize your claim.
g-0: ^n: Now, that's an interesting idea. If we had allies to back our claim, those mud-dwellers wouldn't have a leg to stand on.
^n: It's something I admit I had not considered. I suppose you have more to offer than I realized at first...
^n: Alright, if you can give us your word that others would back us up against the Mudwooders, we'll join your rail network.

s: ^p: Perhaps I was a bit hasty

c-3: ^, I can't give you my word at this time.
^n: I suppose you need to get some things in order before committing... very well.
^n: When you're ready to talk further, you know where to find me.

RiverOfferConfirm: ^n: Wonderful! In that case, I am happy to have New Bridginggale join your little rail project.
^n: Once we have full control over the gold in the river, I'm sure we'll be able to trade it with some of the others for the trinkets they make.
^n: No doubt they'll be grateful just to have contact with a place like New Bridginggale.
Class: ^n: Well, you could say that the people here have a little more... Oh, what's the word... Ah, that's it, "class".
^n: We don't get our hands dirty with mundane work, we have plenty of machines to do all that.
^n: It allows us a life of luxury and style. Something that can be all too hard to come by nowadays.

c-0: ^n: Thank you, I'm glad to meet someone who can appreciate the high life.

Robots: ^n: Oh, you mean the helpers? Yes, those little bots do all the manual labor around here.

c-0: ^n: Hmph, well I wouldn't put it that way. We occasionally need to give the auto-repair units a little jiggle.
^n: We also direct them around, telling them what to do and where to go.
c-1: ^n: Yes, I'm glad to meet someone who can appreciate what we do here. Directing the helpers all day is hard work, don't you know.

HostileRobots: ^n: Oh, you mean the helpers? Yes, those little bots do all the manual labor around here.
^n: They also used to mine down by the river, before you got so many others involved in our conflict with Mudwood.
^n: Those simpletons wouldn't even know what to do with that gold. At least we know how to trade for luxury goods.
MudwoodIntro: ^n: It's much better than walking around in the muck and mud all day, unlike those simpletons in Mudwood.

s: ^p: What do you know about Mudwood?
^p: You have a problem with Mudwood?
^p: Simpletons? Who are you talking about?

g-0: ^n: Oh, it's a tiny little group of buildings on the other side of the river.
^n: The people there are a little more... rough around the edges, if you catch my meaning.
^n: We don't mix with them when we can avoid it, though they can be a nuisance when they try to mine near the river.

s: ^p: Why would they mine near the river?
^p: Why are they such a nuisance?

g-1: ^n: Oh, those simpletons have it in their mind that all the gold veins around the river belong to them.
^n: We clearly laid claim to it, but nearly every day we find they've run off our helpers that are trying to mine the gold.

s: ^p: How did you lay claim to it?
^p: Why do they think it belongs to them?

g-2: ^n: Well, we established our glorious settlment 5 years ago, and when we did we marked off the whole area with mauve ribbons.
^n: The people of Mudwood had clearly never seen something as nice as a ribbon before, and totally ignored the boundary.
^n: They've continued to tresspass into our lands over and over again, and we keep reminding them that we own it.

s: ^p: It sounds like you do own those lands
^p: Does that really mean you own those lands?

c-8: ^ Mauve? Do you mean purple ribbons?
^n: I most certainly do not, I mean mauve. I have a keen eye for colors.
c-9: ^n: I'm sure I don't know what you're talking about. We clearly marked that area with our mauve ribbons, I double checked myself.
^n: I spent a week bathing to get rid of all the dirt from that trip, but it was worth it to confirm we are in the right.
c-10: ^, if you marked the area with ribbons
^n: Precisely. The people in Mudwood must be blind or malicious to continue to say they own those lands.
c-11: ^n: It certainly does. This world was free for anyone to claim, as long as those claims are made explicitly and clearly.
^n: Marking the area with mauve ribbons was an explicit and clear sign that we owned it.

g-3: ^n: Well, in any case, our conflict with Mudwood is neither here nor there.

DanFlustered: ^n: He... he said that, did he? Well, I didn't think that he could... I mean, I suppose he does have his own charms...
^n: I would be lying if I said I hadn't thought about... Ahem, please excuse me, this isn't something I wish to talk about further.
^n: As nice as he may be, his tresspassing on our lands is really something I can't overlook.

b: ^ Dan's the name, Mudwood's muh home. What can I do fer ya?

s: ^p: I'm here on behalf of Trailways Railways and Tradeways
^p: I'm here on behalf of Trailways Railways and Tradeways
^p: Is there anything of note around here?
^p: Is there anything of note around here?
^p: Dellorithy said you look mighty-fine in those overalls.

c-0: ^ I wanted to talk to you about establishing a rail line here.
c-1: ^ I wanted to talk to you about establishing a rail line here.

b: ^Well don't be a stanger, you hear? Come back soon!

MudwoodName: ^n: Yes indeed it is. When we all arrived here, we found a lotta mud and a lotta wood. Called it Mudwood.

g-0: ^n: Heck, the people around here ain't some kinda university scientists. We all work fer a living.
^n: We don't have no time to come up with fancy names fer things, so we calls 'em as we sees 'em.

c-2: ^, that's a good way to handle it.

g-1: ^n: Dern right, now yer gettin' it.

RepresentativeIntro: ^n: Well heck, ain't a mouthful of nonsense. Y'all're building a railroad, right? Why don't ya just say that?
^n: Look, you seem like a nice guy, but we here are... What's the word... Self-soo-fish-ent. We keep to our own.
^n: I don't think we want too many city-slickers runnin' through here all the time.

s: ^p: The railroad could be profitable for you.
^p: You don't see any reason to join?

g-0: ^n: Aw, heck. Like I was sayin', we got everything we need here. Our own little gen-yoo-wine paradise.
^n: Sorry, traveler. Looks like you gotta look somewhere else.

HostileRepresentativeIntro: ^n: Yeah, I heard about yer railroad. I heard you was fixing to help alla them fancy-pants people up in Bridgey-gale.
^n: We don't want nothing to do with that railroad if you got people like that on it.

g-0: ^n: Them people up there says they own that river even though we was the ones that first got to it.
^n: If yer working with them, I don't see how we can see eye-to-eye on nothin'.

RepresentativeConvince: ^n: Like I was tellin' ya before, I don't see that we'd be needing anything fancy like that any time soon.

s: ^p: What if I could help with the river?
^p: The company will help you with the river.
^p: Okay, sorry to bring it up.

c-2: ^n: We ain't gotta do nothin', city-slicker. You best be movin' on.

HostileRepresentativeConvince: ^n: No-way, no-how, we ain't interested in that there railroad.

s: ^p: What if you had a cheap supply of food?
^p: There's nothing I can do to convince you?

c-1: ^n: We got all we need right here in Mudwood, and we don't want nothin' else. You best be leavin'.

Gold: ^n: Well, let's see. There's an ATV track 'round that nearby hill, it's pretty fun.
^n: There's also some good critters you can find in the dead logs in the woods, they cook up real nice.
^n: Oh yeah, and there's also all that gold around.

s: ^p: I'm always looking to try new

g-0: ^n: Yep, them lands around the river are just chock-full o' gold. You can't swing a stick without hittin' some.
^n: We dig it up around there sometimes. Well, when we ain't fightin' off the robots from Bridgey-gale.

s: ^p: Fighting? What are you talking about?

g-1: ^n: Oh, up in Bridgey-gale they got a lot of fancy-pants rich folks that use robots to do all their work.
^n: It's lazy, that's what it is. A person should work with their hands, gettin' down in the muck.
^n: Anyway, they got it in their heads that they own the land 'round the river, even though we claimed it.

s: ^p: How did you lay claim to it?
^p: Why do they think it belongs to them?

g-2: ^n: Well, we rolled up on in here 'bout 5 years back. When we did, we marked off the whole area like we was supposed to.
^n: Used some nice purple ribbons to do it, anyone who seen 'em would know that this land was ours.
^n: But those rich fancy-pantses don't care about the rules, I reckon. They still say they own it.
^n: They send their robots down there from time to time to mine the river, and we gotta fight 'em off.

s: ^p: It sounds like you do own those lands
^p: Does that really mean you own those lands?

c-8: ^n: Mauve? What in the sam-heck is mauve? I said purple, didn't I? I know purple when I sees it.
c-9: ^n: Yeah, all the folks that come to this world are supposed to mark out their territory. I put up the ribbons myself.
^n: Got lost a few times, but I made sure to put 'em up everywhere I saw.
c-10: ^, if you marked the area with ribbons.
^n: That's what I been sayin'! But the folks up in Bridgey-gale don't let a purple ribbon stop them.
^n: People like that, they take what they want, don't matter if it belongs to someone else.
c-11: ^n: You bet it does. First-come-first-serve, that's the law 'round here. We came first, so we get served first.

g-3: ^n: I'm going to get too riled up if I keep talkin' bout this. Better to talk about something else, ya know?

HostileGold: ^n: Well, let's see. There's an ATV track 'round that nearby hill, it's pretty fun.
^n: There's also some good critters you can find in the dead logs in the woods, they cook up real nice.
^n: Oh yeah, there was a bunch of gold around, but you put a stop to all that by helpin' Bridgey-gale.
^n: That was a low blow, traveler. Not sure what else you want around here after taking that.

c-0: ^ If you're part of the network, others would back your claim.
c-1: ^ If you're part of the network, others would back your claim.
g-0: ^n: Well now, I reckon that's a pretty fine idea.
^n: Those big-shots wouldn't be able to do nothin' if more of us were standin' against 'em.
^n: If you gimme yer word that you'll help us out, then we're in!

s: ^p: Actually, I need to do some things first.

c-3: ^n: Well don't go getting our hopes up all fer nothin'. You come back when yer ready to talk.

RiverOfferConfirm: ^n: Well boy howdy, we got ourselves a deal! Let's spit on it.
^n: We'll have more gold than we know what do do with soon.
^n: I'll bet some o' them other cities 'round that railroad might want some, we'll call 'em up right away!
FoodOffer: ^n: Food? Hm, well, I do love me some good cooking. What're ya talking about, exactly?

s: ^p: The farms in Whispering Seeds can help

c-0: ^, they're part of the rail network.
g-0: ^n: Farming? Down in Whispering Seeds? Do they got any good stuff, like corn or okra?

c-2: ^n: Whoo-eee. It's been a while since I had any real good cornbread.
c-3: ^n: Whoo-eee. It's been a while since I had any real good gumbo.

g-1: ^n: If they got fancy foods like that growin' down there, we sure would like to get our hands on some of it.
^n: Aw heck, I can tell you ain't such a bad one. You comin' all the way out here already means a lot.
^n: Tell you what, if joining this here railroad net means we get some good cookin' every once in a while, then we're in.

s: ^p: Glad to have you on board!

g-2: ^n: If you're coming through here again any time soon, stop by my place.
^n: I'll make you some of my double-devil fiery death lava chili. It's the least I can can do fer everythin' you've done.
g-3: ^n: You better believe it! Take care now.

DellorithyComplement: ^n: Well she said that, did she? Aw, that's a mighty nice thing for her to say.
^n: You know, I always tell people 'round here that even if those people in Bridgey-gale are snooty, they ain't all bad.
^n: If they could just stop fightin' us over that there river, we might even be close someday. Maybe someday.
